Description: Stela in limestone, complete. Relief carved in upper part with: to the left, a ram with twisted horns and sun-disc on top of the head, standing on a rectangular base; in front of the ram, an offering pedestal surmounted by breads and lotus flowers; to the right a man wearing a long loincloth, raising his hands in front of him in an attitude of worship; winged sun with two uraei above scene. Below, text of fourteen demotic lines. Remains of red and black painting in relief.
Production date: 3rdC BC (year 3 of Ptolemy II or III)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Kelsey Museum of Archaeology, Michigan. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

When the stela was bought in Cairo in 1927, the provenance was lost. However, the mention in the text of Amun-Ra lord of Baded and of other "great gods of Naukratis (Nay-Keredj)" clearly indicates that it originated from Naukratis.This donation stela, dated to the year 3 of Ptolemy II or III [281/280 or 245/244 BC], is an unusual document since it is a demotic copy of a decree of evergetism made in honour of an individual benefactor, and not a king. Such practice was popular in Greek communities but not in Egypt. The local community of sheep breeders attached to the temples (wlt) made this decree in honour of a local individual, Sheamenope, who rendered services to this community and to the divine ram, hypostasis of Amun-Ra of Naukratis. Sheamenope was in charge of commercialising the wool from Milesian flock produced by the community of the wlt. The stela was probably placed in front of a building or a chapel related to the sacred rams.
